dialog.text: What’s the real difference between storywriting and journaling?
Storywriting builds made-up worlds, arcs, and characters; journaling records your lived moments, thoughts, and feelings.
So one’s for readers, the other for you to know yourself?
Exactly. Storywriting asks questions, creates tension, and aims to move or entertain.
And journaling—doesn’t it flow as private, honest notes about today?
Journaling captures the truth of the present; storywriting reshapes it into craft, meaning, and memory.
Yes. Mine your journals to seed stories, or turn real memories into fictional scenes.
If you found this helpful, try the quick combo I described and share your reflections in the comments.
